channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Burkina Faso President Ousted in Military Coup
item.description: Mutinous officers said the public was fed up with President Roch Marc Christian Kaboré because of his inability to stop attacks by Islamist militants.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds cheering the military takeover in Ouagadougou, the capital of Burkina Faso, on Monday.

item.title: Threatened and Beaten, Afghan Women Defy Taliban With Protests
item.description: The Taliban have begun cracking down harder as women insist on their rights and as Western governments call for reforms.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Yaqoob Akbary
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesting for women’s rights under the Taliban in Kabul, Afghanistan, in October.

item.title: NATO Steps Up Readiness in Eastern Europe to Reassure Allies
item.description: The alliance is sending more jets and ships to the region. The decision comes as Britain joined the U.S. in withdrawing the families of diplomats in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on the frontlines in the city of Avdiivka on Sunday.

item.title: US Troops Join Kurdish-Led Forces in Assault on Prison Held by ISIS
item.description: The Islamic State seized a prison in Syria to try to free thousands of fellow jihadists and is using hundreds of imprisoned boys as human shields.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces patrolling Hasaka, Syria, on Monday.

item.title: Germany's Vaccine Mandate Forges Unlikely Coalition of Protestors
item.description: The prospect of a vaccine mandate has galvanized a nationwide protest movement attracting naturalists, neo-Nazis and ordinary citizens alike.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: An anti-vaccine protest in Nuremberg, Germany, this month. Organized resistance to vaccines in Germany is significant, and brings together varying political groups.

item.title: Benedict Admits Being at Meeting About Priest Accused of Abuse
item.description: A statement by the former pope contradicted a previous statement to a law firm investigating allegations of child sex abuse by priests when he was an archbishop.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Pope Benedict XVI in 2010. A report released last week said the former pope mishandled at least four cases of sexual abuse accusations when he was an archbishop in Germany.

item.title: U.S. Helps Thwart Attack by Yemen Rebels on American Air Base in U.A.E.
item.description: The Houthi rebels fired two missiles at a base in Abu Dhabi where 2,000 Americans are stationed, the latest salvo in their escalating war with a Saudi-led coalition that includes the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Listening to a Houthi spokesman delivering a statement about attacks on Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates in Sanaa, Yemen, on Monday.

item.title: Julian Assange Can Appeal Decision to Extradite Him to U.S., U.K. Court Rules
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder has argued that American prison conditions would be harmful to his mental health. He faces a lengthy sentence if convicted on espionage charges.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Charlie Savage
item.media:description: Supporters of Julian Assange outside the Royal Courts of Justice in London on Monday.

item.title: A Newly Reported Gathering, and a New Headache for Johnson
item.description: The news came the same day as Mr. Johnson ordered an inquiry into a lawmaker’s claim of Islamophobia.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

item.title: Saad Hariri, Lebanon’s Former Prime Minister, Quits Politics
item.description: He was the leader of the country’s Sunni Muslims, one of the three main sects that share power, and the scion of a prominent political dynasty.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Saad Hariri, the former prime minister of Lebanon, announced his withdrawal from political life on Monday at a news conference in his home in Beirut.

item.title: Italians Vote for a President. Here’s Why It Matters.
item.description: The normally mundane ritual of electing a president every seven years has turned more fateful this year, with Italy’s political stability potentially hanging in the balance.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: If elected, Mario Draghi would be the first prime minister to ascend to the Italian presidency.

item.title: ‘Now There Is No One’: The Lament of One of the Last Christians in a Syrian City
item.description: Michel Butros al-Jisri is among the few Christians left from a once-vibrant community in Idlib on the brink of disappearing. The city, in the only territory in Syria still controlled by rebels, is ruled by Islamists.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad, Asmaa al-Omar and Ben Hubbard

item.title: Omicron’s spread could lead to ‘stabilization and normalization,’ a top W.H.O. official says.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: A Covid-19 intensive care unit in Cremona, Italy, this month.

item.title: China lifts a monthlong lockdown on the 13 million residents of the city of Xi’an.
item.dc:creator: John Liu and Paul Mozur
item.media:description: Spraying disinfectant in a residential area in Xi’an on Sunday as the Chinese city starts to reopen.

item.title: Omicron Offers Hope Pandemic Could Stabilize, W.H.O. Official Says.
item.description: The rapid spread of the variant means far more people will have some immunity, at least for now, which might bode well this year for highly vaccinated countries in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Marc Santora
item.media:description: A Covid-19 intensive care unit in Cremona, Italy, this month.

item.title: At Least 6 Killed in Crush at African Cup Match
item.description: Witnesses said the stadium stewards closed the gates and stopped allowing people in, setting off the crush.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Cameroon fans inside Olembe Stadium on Monday in Yaounde.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: 8,500 Troops on ‘High Alert’
item.description: U.S. and NATO allies make plans in case of Russian military action.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: U.S. soldiers of the NATO Extended Presence Battlegroup participated in a military exercise in Latvia last March.

item.title: Pentagon Puts 8,500 Troops on ‘High Alert’ Amid Ukraine Tensions
item.description: The move signals a shift for the Biden administration as the United States and NATO allies brace for possible Russian military action.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most of the 8,500 troops would take part in a NATO response force that might soon be activated, John F. Kirby, the Pentagon spokesman, said on Monday.

item.title: Irish Police Investigate Mysterious Death in Post Office
item.description: The police said a man was found dead in a post office where pensions were collected. Witnesses told the Irish media that two men had brought him there to collect his funds.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin

item.title: Covid setbacks to schooling are ‘nearly insurmountable,’ the U.N. says.
item.description: Many millions of children have “significantly missed out” on the academic learning they would have acquired in the classroom, the United Nations Children’s Fund said in a new report.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eric, left, and Quita Shorty, from Atlanta, are among millions of schoolchildren who have endured extended periods away from the classroom.

item.title: Stowaway Survives Flight to Amsterdam in a Plane's Wheel Bay
item.description: The police are investigating how a 22-year-old man from Kenya got onto the flight, which took off in Johannesburg and stopped in Nairobi.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Arthur Van Der Kooij/Agence France-Presse, via ANP
item.media:description: Schiphol Airport, near Amsterdam. The Dutch police said that they had found a man, alive and in stable condition, in the wheel section of a cargo plane that arrived from South Africa on Sunday.

item.title: Personal Profit in Congress
item.description: Some members of Congress have strangely good timing when it comes to stock investments.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Senators Richard Burr and Dianne Feinstein sold stocks after a private briefing on Covid-19.

item.title: Can a New Line of Work Help Save These Wild Welsh Ponies?
item.description: A longstanding source of local pride and affection, Welsh mountain ponies have seen many of their traditional roles vanish. A new initiative aims to ensure their continued survival.
item.dc:creator: Claire Thomas
item.media:description: Horses are much-loved pets and companions throughout Wales.

item.title: Rich Countries Lure Health Workers From Low-Income Nations to Fight Shortages
item.description: Huge pay incentives and immigration fast-tracks are leading many to leave countries whose health systems urgently need their expertise.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: Alex Mulumba, a nurse at a critical care hospital in Lusaka, Zambia, is considering moving to Canada for better pay. He currently earns $415 per month.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Biden weighs a pivot on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: U.S. soldiers of the NATO Extended Presence Battlegroup participated in a military exercise in Latvia last March.

item.title: U.S. Orders Family Members of Embassy Staff to Leave Ukraine
item.description: The State Department warned that the United States would “not be in a position” to evacuate U.S. citizens should Russia invade.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner, Edward Wong and Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Thierry Mugler, Genre-Busting French Fashion Designer, Dies at 73
item.description: The dominatrix-loving couturier turned sex into a style weapon.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Bernstein
item.media:description: The designer Manfred Thierry Mugler at his fall 2001 fashion show in Paris.

item.title: Biden Weighs Deploying Thousands of Troops to Eastern Europe and Baltics
item.description: The president is also considering deploying warships and aircraft to NATO allies, in what would be a major shift from its restrained stance on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: U.S. soldiers of the NATO Extended Presence Battlegroup participated in a military exercise in Latvia last March.

item.title: As U.S. Strikes Syria Prison Held by ISIS, Young Detainees Are Caught in Crossfire
item.description: Almost 700 child detainees are being held in the prison still under siege four days after ISIS launched an attack to free detainees
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Syrian Democratic Forces fighters taking position near the prison on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: A U.K. Accusation
item.description: British officials say Russia is trying to establish a pro-Kremlin government in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: French Adventurer Attempting to Row Solo Across the Atlantic Is Missing
item.description: Jean-Jacques Savin, 75, activated distress beacons on Thursday and Friday, his team said. On Saturday, the Portuguese Navy found his boat, but not his body, near the Azores.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: Jean-Jacques Savin, 75, who crossed the Atlantic Ocean in a barrel in 2019 before setting off again on January 1, 2022 to row across it, set off his distress beacons on January 21, 2022 and his team has “no further contact” since then, they say on January 22, 2022.

item.title: In Greece, a String of Killings Pushes Domestic Abuse Into the Spotlight
item.description: Several deadly assaults on women by their partners appear to have encouraged more victims to speak up in a country where such attacks have rarely been publicly discussed.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: A rally in Athens in June against domestic violence. The rise in abuse mirrors increases elsewhere that, in part, appear to be a side effect of Covid lockdowns.

item.title: In Wuhan, China, Anniversary of First Covid Lockdown Passes Quietly
item.description: As China battles the highly contagious Omicron variant shortly before the Winter Olympics are set to begin in Beijing, Wuhan has so far been spared.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Playing in Wuhan, China, last week.

item.title: Gunfire Rattles Burkina Faso’s Capital as Soldiers Revolt
item.description: The government denied rumors of a coup, but soldiers who want changes to the fight against Islamists appear to have taken control of several military bases.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police used tear gas to disperse crowds in central Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, on Sunday.

item.title: Pakistan says only fully vaccinated people will be allowed in mosques.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Pakistani officials said only fully vaccinated people would be allowed into mosques for prayer.

item.title: Virtual schooling hurt students. So why is the federal government paying for virtual tutoring?
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Even as in-person classes have resumed, many students are being tutored online. Labor difficulties and the costs of high-quality tutoring programs are big factors.

item.title: Coronavirus tests from the U.S. government have begun to arrive at some homes.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Deliveries of at-home coronavirus test kits are starting to arrive in Americans’ mail boxes after orders began to be placed on a government website on Tuesday.

item.title: For Winter Olympians, the last hurdle before the competition is staying healthy.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:credit: Rick Elvin/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Canadian men’s curling team is isolating away from families and friends to try to avoid the coronavirus ahead of the Beijing Olympics.

item.title: For small U.S. towns, just one coronavirus infection can put governance at risk.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Houston Cofield for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lee Guest is the mayor of Marvell, Ark., as well as the assistant fire chief and a mail carrier.

item.title: Cameroon Nightclub Fire Kills at Least 16
item.description: The blaze was caused by explosions from fireworks used in the venue, the government said in a statement reported by news agencies.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Livs Night Club in Yaoundé, Cameroon, on Sunday. Two explosions at the venue were said to have caused a stampede.

item.title: Britain Pursues More Muscular Role in Standoff With Russia on Ukraine
item.description: With a late-night announcement about Russian meddling in Ukraine, the U.K. signaled its aim to be a player in Europe’s security crisis — even as scandals besiege Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A convoy of Russian armored vehicles on the move in Crimea on Tuesday. Britain is adopting a harder line against Russia amid fears of a possible invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: How a Nostalgic Novel About Spain’s Heartland Joined the Political Fray
item.description: Ana Iris Simón wrote “Feria” to depict a way of life she fears is vanishing. She didn’t expect its message to be embraced by conservatives in her country.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Ben Roberts for The New York Times
item.media:description: “People have been reading my book as if it were the new ‘Mein Kampf,’” Ana Iris Simón said, “and they then are writing to me to say that they are disappointed to find that it has neither the strong political message that they had hoped for, nor the content that they had heard about.”

item.title: As New York reports glimmers of hope, states in the West are under pressure.
item.dc:creator: Esha Ray
item.media:description: Thomas Hoang, 29, of Emergency Ambulance Service, dropping off a Covid patient at an emergency room in Placentia, Calif., this month.

item.title: ‘Miserable and Dangerous’: A Failed Chinese Promise in Serbia
item.description: Poor conditions for Vietnamese workers building a $900 million tire factory underscore a chasm between the promise of investment from China and grim realities on the ground.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Marko Risovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ling Long Tire factory construction site in Zrenjanin, Serbia. Vietnamese workers say they face “miserable and dangerous” conditions on the site.

item.title: Britain Says Moscow Is Plotting to Install a Pro-Russian Leader in Ukraine
item.description: In a highly unusual public statement, backed by U.S. officials, London named the putative head of a potential puppet government but few other details.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, David E. Sanger and Mark Landler
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at the border with Russia. The Russians have deployed thousands of troops nearby and, according to a British assessment, are seeking to install a new government in Ukraine.

item.title: Winter Olympic Torch Relay Shrinks to ‘Prioritize Safety.’
item.description: The relay, usually global and lasting for months, will take place over just three days, be mostly local, and only select members of the public will be able to attend.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: The torches for the 2022 Winter Olympics, left, and Paralympic Games on display at the Beijing Capital Museum this month.

item.title: Why Boris Johnson May Finally Have Gone Too Far
item.description: Moral hypocrisy, such as lying about parties held during Britain’s lockdown, is the ultimate sin in human society, with a special power to enrage.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain at a virtual news conference this month. Mr. Johnson has apologized for attending a garden party amid pandemic restrictions.

item.title: ‘Why Was I Born a Girl?’ An Afghan Poem Inspires U.S. Students
item.description: A Zoom connection between high schoolers in Afghanistan and San Diego opens a window for mutual support.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Jim Huylebroek

item.title: China is staging the Winter Olympics on its own terms.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers, Keith Bradsher and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Young skiers at one of the venues in northern China that will be used for the 2022 Olympics. After winning the Games, Xi Jinping decreed that China would become a winter sports wonderland.

item.title: Stocks are off to their worst start of a year since 2016.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
item.media:credit: Courtney Crow/New York Stock Exchange, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A stock trader works on the floor, Friday, January 21, as the stock market fell for the fourth day in a row.

item.title: English Island Seeks a Landlord-King Who Likes Solitude, Seals and Beer
item.description: On Piel Island, winters are wet, travel is limited, and the solitary pub crowns the landlord king or queen under a shower of beer.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: The Ship Inn and Piel Castle are the primary landmarks on Piel Island, off the northwestern coast of England. The local council is searching for a landlord to maintain the island and run the pub.

item.title: Drake Put Toronto on the Map. A University Put Him in the Syllabus
item.description: The hip-hop star’s influence on Toronto has been enormous and now includes a Ryerson University course deconstructing him.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Drake performing in Austin, Texas, in 2016.

item.title: Thich Nhat Hanh: Quotes From a Zen Master
item.description: “People talk about entering nirvana, but we are already there,” said the Buddhist monk, who died on Saturday. Here is a short selection of his remarks.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thich Nhat Hanh at his temple in Hue, Vietnam, in 2019.

item.title: How China's Xi Jinping Is Staging the Beijing Olympics on His Terms
item.description: From Beijing’s unexpected bid through the coronavirus pandemic, China has managed to fulfill its promises and cow its critics.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers, Keith Bradsher and Tariq Panja
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader. Mr. Xi put his personal prestige on the line when China bid to host the 2022 Winter Games, and the country has come through on its promises.

item.title: What a Potential Russian Invasion Means in Chernobyl
item.description: Ukraine has initiated a defensive strategy for the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, one of the most radioactive places on Earth, which lies on the shortest path between Russia and Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: The abandoned town of Prypiat, Ukraine, near the Ukraine-Belarus border. The town was evacuated on April 27, 1986, the day after the Chernobyl disaster.

item.title: Fugees Cancel Reunion Tour, Citing the Pandemic
item.description: A tour to recognize the 25th anniversary of a career-defining album will have to wait.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: The Fugees performing during the Global Citizen Live concert in New York City in September.

item.title: Tonga Tsunami Brought Catastrophe to 3 Tiny Islands
item.description: The sparsely populated islets of Nomuka, Mango and Fonoifua were hit by waves almost 50 feet high, a Red Cross official said.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Defence Public Affairs, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An aerial view of Fonoifua, an island in Tonga, on Tuesday, days after the tsunami. Just two homes were left intact.

item.title: F.D.A. Approves Remdesivir for Patients Not Hospitalized
item.description: The treatment must be given via intravenous infusion over three consecutive days, generally at a hospital or clinic.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Remdesivir, an antiviral medication, has been widely used in hospitals to treat Covid since the early days of the pandemic.

item.title: Arizona sues to try to keep U.S. from clawing back relief funds.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona is suing the Biden administration over its attempt to recoup stimulus funds.
